questions.question: What is the most widely used distributed version control system?
questions.explanation: Git is the most popular distributed version control system, used by millions of developers worldwide for tracking code changes.

questions.question: What Git command creates a new independent line of development?
questions.explanation: git branch creates a new branch, allowing developers to work on features or fixes independently from the main codebase.

questions.question: What operation combines changes from one branch into another?
questions.explanation: Merge combines changes from one branch into another, integrating different lines of development.

questions.question: What Git command downloads a copy of a remote repository?
questions.explanation: git clone creates a local copy of a remote repository, including all files, branches, and commit history.

questions.question: Which operation rewrites commit history by moving commits to a new base?
questions.explanation: Rebase moves or combines commits to a new base commit, creating a linear history without merge commits.

questions.question: What is a request to merge code changes from one branch to another called?
questions.explanation: A Pull Request is a GitHub feature that lets you notify others about changes you've pushed to a branch, requesting review and merge.

questions.question: What situation occurs when two branches modify the same part of code differently?
questions.explanation: A Merge Conflict occurs when Git cannot automatically resolve differences between two commits, requiring manual resolution.

questions.question: What workflow uses short-lived feature branches merged frequently?
questions.explanation: Trunk-Based Development involves developers working in short-lived feature branches that are frequently merged back to the main trunk.

questions.question: What Git command temporarily saves changes without committing?
questions.explanation: git stash temporarily stores modified tracked files, allowing you to switch branches without committing incomplete work.

questions.question: What creates a named reference to a specific commit?
questions.explanation: A Tag is a reference to a specific commit, typically used to mark release points like v1.0, v2.0, etc.
